image.altText: A white and purple passenger plane on a runway.

props.synopsis: The budget carrier has announced its arrival into the NT's aviation market, and is promising to provide more competition and lower fares to tourists and locals.

title.children: Budget airline Bonza announces new flight routes to and from the Northern Territory

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

props.synopsis: Former Qantas CEO Alan Joyce was paid $21.4 million in the last financial year, but more than half could be subjected to a clawback by the airline's board.

title.children: Qantas paid former CEO Alan Joyce $21.4 million last financial year

image.altText: The tails of Qantas planes showing the flying kangaroo pass each other at Sydney Airport.

props.synopsis: The Qantas CEO is ordered into mediation with the workers' union, the Senate holds a hearing into regional bank closures by major banks, and the ASX is in negative territory this afternoon.

title.children: Alan Joyce's remuneration revealed as new Qantas CEO ordered into mediation with Transport Workers' Union

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ASX 200: -0.45% to 7,163 points (close) All Ords: -0.5% to 7,361 points (close) Australian dollar: 64.60 US cents Nikkei: -0.66%, to 33,023 points Hang Seng: -0.47%, to 17,914 points Dow Jones -0.3%, to 34,517 points S & P 500 -0.2%, to 4,443 points FTSE: 0.54%, to 7,701 points DAX: 0.3%, to 15,719 points Gold: $1,928 US/ounce Iron ore: $123.5 Brent crude: $93.48 Bitcoin: $27,113
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market snapshot at 6pm AEST

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Alan Joyce's total pay outcome for 2022/23 was $21.4 million. The financial report says the 2022/23 short-term incentive plan (STIP) is not included in that figure. It says the 2022/23 STIP and the 2021/23 long-term incentive plan (LTIP) remain subject to Board discretion and clawback should the Board determine that this is necessary. The full extent of the CEO's remuneration subject to clawback and/or malus is up to $14.4 million as set out in the body of the financial report. Statutory remuneration was $11.9 million. What about the recent converting of Rights to shares by Mr Joyce? The report says after offering in previous years to defer the decision on vesting of Rights awarded under the 2018-2020 LTIP, 2019-2021 LTIP and the 2020-2022 LTIP, Joyce elected in August 2023 to convert these Rights to shares. " The combined value of these three LTIPs contributed $6.45 million to the CEO's actual outcome of $21.4 million for 2022/23 ," the report says
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Alan Joyce's total remuneration is $21.4 million for 2022/23

children.content: Alan Joyce's total pay outcome for 2022/23 was
The financial report says the 2022/23 short-term incentive plan (STIP) is not included in that figure.
It says the 2022/23 STIP and the 2021/23 long-term incentive plan (LTIP)
remain subject to Board discretion and clawback should the Board determine that this is necessary.
The full extent of the CEO's remuneration subject to clawback and/or malus
as set out in the body of the financial report.
What about the recent converting of Rights to shares by Mr Joyce?

The report says after offering in previous years to defer the decision on vesting of Rights awarded under the 2018-2020 LTIP, 2019-2021 LTIP and the 2020-2022 LTIP, Joyce elected in August 2023 to convert these Rights to shares.
The combined value of these three LTIPs contributed $6.45 million to the CEO's actual outcome of $21.4 million for 2022/23

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Alright, let's turn things over to Qantas for now. The airline has just released its annual report without warning, and after 3pm on a Wednesday. As far as media management goes, it means lots of TV stations will now have very little time to produce a story for tonight's TV news. What could be in it?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas has released its annual report, after 3pm

children.content: Alright, let's turn things over to Qantas for now.
The airline has just released its annual report without warning, and after 3pm on a Wednesday.
As far as media management goes, it means lots of TV stations will now have very little time to produce a story for tonight's TV news.

image.altText: A pile of ants with large, swollen abdomens full of honey, on red soil.

props.synopsis: A study finds secretions from the abdomen of the honeypot ant possess unique antimicrobial properties that make it effective against the golden staph bacteria.

title.children: Could this traditional Indigenous medicine one day help treat deadly golden staph?

image.altText: Headshots of Prince William, PennyWong and Volodomyr Zelenskyy

props.synopsis: World leaders converge in New York City for the biggest gathering of global decision-makers since COVID. Here are some takeaways from day one of this year's UN General Assembly meeting.

title.children: 'Our world is becoming unhinged': Here's what happened on day one of the UN's big annual meeting

image.altText: Richard Scolyer holds up his hands while speaking at the National Press Club

props.synopsis: Richard Scolyer is at the forefront of melanoma treatment and research, but a devastating cancer diagnosis of his own has made him the self-described "patient zero" in a new frontier of brain cancer treatment.

title.children: 'Nothing short of phenomenal': Cancer expert undergoing experimental treatment reporting promising results

image.altText: Image from Twitter of New York Times ad.

props.synopsis: Over 200 climate scientists have taken out a full-page ad in the New York Times calling out Australia's "climate annihilation", while Fijian activists impacted by rising sea levels urge Canberra to do more.

title.children: Scientists take out full-page New York Times ad calling on Australia to end ‘climate annihilation’

image.altText: a young man smiling in front of street art

props.synopsis: A tropical Northern Territory town is turning once ordinary buildings and shopfronts into colourful street murals.

title.children: How an explosion of colourful street art is transforming this regional NT town

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie runs his hand over his hair while standing between two people

props.synopsis: A police interview with Danushka Gunathilaka played before the court shows the Sri Lankan cricketer crying and recalling the pair's interaction.

title.children: Cricketer Danushka Gunathilaka found sexual assault accuser 'a bit weird' after talk of past lives, court hears

image.altText: Man stands inside small plane with door open cleaning it

props.synopsis: Arnhem Land missionaries cleared dense bushland and eventually trained the first Yolngu aviation mechanic and pilot.

title.children: Airstrips were built before roads in an outback land where walking was the main mode of transport

image.altText: Varroa mite nestled on a bee, with a blue circle identifying it on the body

props.synopsis: Australia has decided it is no longer technically feasible to eradicate varroa mite and will move to management of the pest.

title.children: Australia abandons efforts to eradicate deadly parasite varroa mite after 15 months

image.altText: A man with sunglasses stands on the beach with his arms folded.

props.synopsis: The search for fugitive gunman Stanley Turvey is over after police shot him dead at Ardmona, near the northern Victorian city of Shepparton.

title.children: Fugitive Stanley Turvey shot dead by police in northern Victoria after three-day manhunt

image.altText: Two police officers arresting a man with grey hair

props.synopsis: A 68-year-old man is expected to be extradited from Victoria to the ACT, after being arrested over the Canberra cold case killing of Irma Palasics.

title.children: Man arrested in Melbourne over the 1999 murder of Canberra woman Irma Palasics

image.altText: A mural featuring the image of a man in a turban

props.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says Australia has raised concerns with India about a fatal shooting in Canada, which that country has blamed on India-backed agents.

title.children: Australia raises concerns with India over allegations it sent assassins to kill Sikh leader in Canada

image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin with his wife and daughter

props.synopsis: When Prigozhin staged a mutiny against Putin's military, he effectively signed his own death warrant. But what happens to his wife and children?

title.children: Before he died in a fiery crash, Prigozhin's family lived a life of opulence. Now they have a choice

image.altText: Geonet quake

props.synopsis: A magnitude-6 earthquake strikes near Geraldine in the centre of New Zealand's South Island.

title.children: New Zealand hit by magnitude-6 earthquake, no serious damage reported

image.altText: young woman address media

props.synopsis: The inquest is examining the disappearance of Tina Louise Greer, who went missing from her Beechmont home in the Gold Coast hinterland in 2012.

title.children: 'I refuse to be silenced': Daughter of suspected murder victim Tina Greer speaks out over 'systematic failures'

image.altText: bishop christopher saunders seated by altar

props.synopsis: After extracts of the Vatican's inquiry into Bishop Christopher Saunders were made public, WA's police force and Attorney-General have requested the Holy See hand over the full report.

title.children: Pressure mounts on the Vatican to hand over report detailing WA bishop sexual misconduct allegations

image.altText: Five First Nations dancers squatting down low outside.

props.synopsis: Two Indigenous teenagers want their peers to shake off a feeling of cultural "shame", while a Yes23 campaigner says a Voice to Parliament will help First Nations children feel proud of their heritage.

title.children: 'Everything is known as shame': Why some First Nations teens are finding it hard to discuss the Voice

image.altText: Two army personnel standing outside a brick home.

props.synopsis: The pilot, who has not been identified by the Marine Corps, did not have serious injuries and has been discharged from the hospital.

title.children: Pilot of downed F-35 fighter jet parachuted safely into a backyard

image.altText: Local Bribie Island residents walked the beach with buckets picking up the small pieces of plastic.

props.synopsis: A multi-agency clean up is underway after about 40,000 tiny pieces of plastic were released into the ocean with some washing up onto beaches on Queensland's Bribie Island.

title.children: About 40,000 tiny pieces of plastic accidentally released into ocean at Bribie Island from CSIRO facility

image.altText: A smartphone with an Airbnb logo on it in front of the same logo being projected on a screen.

props.synopsis: Short-stay rental platforms, such as Airbnb and Stayz, will face a 7.5 per cent levy from 2025, the Victorian government says.

title.children: Short-stay tax, social housing rebuild announced in Victorian policy roadmap

image.altText: a flowering paddock of yellow safflower

props.synopsis: Promoted as an oilseed alternative to petrochemicals, safflower is left sitting uncollected in silos across the country with its exclusive developer unable to pay contracted farmers.

title.children: Why a crop heralded as an alternative to petroleum is sitting idle in farm silos

image.altText: In a light room filled with shelves of ceramics, a smiling woman paints a vase and smiling man molds clay on wheel.

props.synopsis: Hobbies aren't just activities to pass the time. They can boost your mental health and sense of purpose. These experts say it's time to take them more seriously.

title.children: Hobbies are for 'pure pleasure'. Here's how to find yours

image.altText: Woman curling up on bed while clutching her stomach

props.synopsis: One in seven women aged between 44 and 49 live with the chronic disease as more are getting diagnosed early, a new report finds.

title.children: Endometriosis hospitalisation rate almost doubles, with 20-24 age group seeing the biggest increase, report shows

image.altText: An emotional Bryan Beattie standing with family and friends outside court

props.synopsis: A Supreme Court judge has found a 14-year-old boy not guilty of murder, despite his involvement in a frenzied gang attack that claimed the life of a teenager in Melbourne's north last year.

title.children: Father wipes away tears after 14yo involved in fatal attack on Declan Cutler found not guilty of murder

image.altText: A crowd of people dance in the foreground, in front of a pavillion in the background.

props.synopsis: A national survey finds Australians are attending fewer arts events, but more people believe things like concerts and festivals can improve their wellbeing.

title.children: Australians attending fewer arts events and festivals, as rising ticket prices and cost of living bite

image.altText: close up of packets of lamb cutlets on Coles shelf

props.synopsis: With some lambs and sheep selling for as little as $2 a head, why are consumers only just starting to see minor price cuts at the supermarket?

title.children: Why are consumers missing out as lamb prices plummet at the saleyards?

image.altText: Peter Dutton wearing black glasses standing in front of a blurry australian flag looking straight toward the camera

props.synopsis: Australia quietly cancels plans to buy reconnaissance drones used by China and Russia under a $1 billion Navy project controversially approved just days before last year's election by then defence minister Peter Dutton.

title.children: Dutton dubs Labor scrapping billion-dollar military drone plan 'contemptible'

image.altText: Watercolour map of Australia showing low amounts of rainfall across the country with ocean in background.

props.synopsis: It was Peruvian fishermen, hundreds of years ago, who first noticed and named El Niño. Little did they realise they had named one of the most consequential climate drivers on Earth. This is how it works.

title.children: In Australia, El Niño has been linked to some of the worst droughts in modern history. Here's how it works

image.altText: A young woman in a wheelchair is in a horse stable, she smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: Jessie Smith pushes through intense pain to ride horses, while Noella Angel says her horse is her reason to get up in the morning.

title.children: Jessie has the most painful disease in the world. Here's how she copes

image.altText: A Camptosaurus skeleton on a black box

props.synopsis: Barry, an almost completely intact Camptosaurus, is expected to fetch almost $2 million at auction.

title.children: A 150-million-year-old dinosaur skeleton named Barry is on sale in Paris

image.altText: ocean grove

props.synopsis: Police say two girls got into trouble in the water at Ocean Grove, near Geelong. One girl died at the scene and another had to be rescued.

title.children: Life Saving Victoria issues warning after 12yo girl drowns at Bellarine Peninsula beach

image.altText: Milk on supermarket shelf showing price

props.synopsis: As consumers adjust to the impact of the rising cost of living, Coles has increased its own-brand milk price by 10 cents per litre. But for farmers, it feels like redemption.

title.children: Why Coles has 'reluctantly' raised the price of its milk this week

image.altText: Singapore President Halimah Yacob (left) refused clemency for Prabu N Pathmanathan.

props.synopsis: Standing at just 1.55 metres and wearing a tudung, the 69-year-old grandmother will be remembered as a low-key and hard-working president who dug into Singapore's vast reserves during the pandemic and never forgot the single-parent family she came from, writes Jason Dasey.

title.children: Singapore's first female president changed perceptions of what Asian leaders should look like
